Explanation: A protein involved in lipid metabolism, primarily found in HDL cholesterol, which helps to remove excess cholesterol from tissues.
A protein component of LDL cholesterol, which is crucial in lipid metabolism and is associated with cardiovascular risk.
A measure of body fat based on height and weight. It is used to assess if an individual is underweight, normal weight, overweight, or obese.
An essential mineral important for bone health, muscle function, and nerve signaling.
A waste product from muscle metabolism that is filtered out by the kidneys; high levels can indicate impaired kidney function.
A form of hemoglobin used to monitor long-term glucose control in individuals with diabetes.
High-density lipoprotein cholesterol, often termed "good" cholesterol, helps to transport cholesterol from the bloodstream to the liver.
Measurement of an individual’s height while standing; used in various health assessments.
The pressure within the left eye, adjusted for corneal thickness; important for diagnosing glaucoma.
The pressure within the right eye, adjusted for corneal thickness; important for diagnosing glaucoma.
The sum of all cholesterol types in the blood, including HDL, LDL, and VLDL; a high total cholesterol level can indicate an increased risk of heart disease.
The lower number in a blood pressure measurement, indicating the pressure in the arteries when the heart rests between beats.
The higher number in a blood pressure measurement, indicating the pressure in the arteries when the heart beats.
The age at which an individual was first diagnosed with high blood pressure (hypertension).
The count of cancers an individual has reported having; used to assess cancer history and risk.
An enzyme found in the liver; elevated levels can indicate liver damage or inflammation.
A protein produced by the liver; low levels can indicate liver disease or kidney problems.
An enzyme related to the liver and bones; elevated levels can indicate liver disease or bone disorders.
An enzyme found in the liver and other tissues; high levels can indicate liver damage or disease.
A protein produced by the liver in response to inflammation; high levels can indicate inflammation or infection.
A form of bilirubin that is processed by the liver; elevated levels can indicate liver dysfunction or bile duct obstruction.
A type of sugar found in the blood; high levels can indicate diabetes or other metabolic disorders.
A hormone similar to insulin that plays a role in growth and development; levels can be affected by growth hormone levels.
Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, often termed "bad" cholesterol, which can lead to plaque buildup in arteries.
A type of lipoprotein associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease.
Small amounts of albumin in the urine; elevated levels can indicate early kidney damage.
An essential mineral involved in bone health and energy production; abnormal levels can indicate various health issues.
The amount of potassium excreted in urine; important for assessing kidney function and electrolyte balance.
A protein that binds sex hormones (like testosterone and estrogen) in the blood; levels can influence hormone activity.
The amount of sodium excreted in urine; important for assessing kidney function and fluid balance.
A hormone involved in male reproductive health and various bodily functions; levels can affect mood, energy, and overall health.
The total amount of bilirubin in the blood; elevated levels can indicate liver problems or anemia.
The total amount of protein in the blood, including albumin and globulins; low levels can indicate liver or kidney problems.
A type of fat in the blood; high levels can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.
A waste product formed from the breakdown of purines; high levels can lead to gout or kidney stones.
A waste product formed from protein metabolism; high levels can indicate kidney dysfunction.
A vitamin important for bone health, immune function, and overall well-being; deficiency can lead to various health problems.
A chronic condition characterized by high blood sugar levels due to insufficient insulin production or action.
A group of progressive lung diseases that cause breathing difficulties, including chronic bronchitis and emphysema.
A condition where the kidneys gradually lose function over time, leading to kidney failure.
A condition characterized by consistently high blood pressure levels, which can lead to heart disease and other health issues.
A chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, causing difficulty in breathing.
